Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Socio-technical systems and Big Data Analytics in the Ebola Response

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In response to the 2014 Ebola virus outbreak in western Africa, dozens of humanitarian relief organizations as well as the CDC and U.S. military are providing medical assistance or logistics support to the relief effort. At the same time, a diverse range of volunteer technical communities (VTCs) and academics, as well as the humanitarian relief organizations themselves, are attempting to make use of "big data" to improve the response. These big data analyses are based on diverse data from diverse sources, including call records from mobile phone companies, health worker inventories from ministries, and daily case-data reports aggregated from multiple organizations. The analyses have generated outputs such as visually appealing maps and predictions of outbreak trajectories. However, precisely how, when and where these analyses can be used effectively by response organizations are still open questions. The project will develop knowledge to guide response organizations interested in leveraging existing and emerging big data from a variety of sources (response organizations, firms, government, individuals), which in turn may improve the speed, quality, and efficiency of crisis response.

The research team of computer and social scientists will partner with a consultant with expertise in crisis information management deployed in the Ebola response. They will examine both organizational and technical dimensions of the use of big data analytics in the Ebola response organizations, carrying out a series of interviews to investigate how and where data is used (field, headquarters, or both) and the work involved to make big data analyses usable in the decision making of response organizations. The results will inform the development of a socio-technical systems framework to explain what makes big data analyses useable. The social dimensions of the framework will include the response context as well as decision making processes. The technical dimensions will include data availability, data analyses and output formats. In the process of developing this socio-technical framework, this research will identify mechanisms for matching organizational needs with big data analyses. More importantly, however, by identifying these mechanisms, the research will shed light on the fundamental roles of multi-level governance and articulation work in making effective use of big data analyses. The multi-level approach helps explain and predict the location in an organization?s hierarchy of technical and decision making expertise. Within these levels, a focus on articulation work helps specify the necessary tasks for using data in a highly dynamic environment. The project will extend the scholarship in the crisis informatics sub-field of big data beyond its current focus on social media data and provide clarification of "last mile" issues in big data aimed at ensuring the usefulness of output.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project 'Socio-technical systems and Big Data Analytics in the Ebola Response' has contributed to the scholarship of cyber-human systems by providing a critical analysis of the hyperbole surrounding the potential of Big Data in the Ebola response. Importantly, we illuminate the need for more nuanced understanding of where in an operational context analyses of large data sets can be used in decision making. We also further develop institutional theory by integrating concepts from the scholarship of online work as well as provide insight for data managers in engaged in humanitarian response. 

Our empirical research into the Ebola response, based on data collected via interviews with humanitarian aid workers physically involved in the response as well as through an online digital humanitarian community of practice, finds the following. First, it suggests big data primarily were used for higher level evaluations somewhat disconnected from day-to-day operations. Second, our research highlights the well understood but continuing need for robust network infrastructure in order to fulfill the potential of Big Data. The data must be collected in remote locations where crises occur and then transmitted on a regular basis. Absent such infrastructure data are sparse and unreliable.  Third, our work identified the critical role of brokers in fostering the development of large datasets. This process of 'data development' requires extensive inter-organizational coordination, built on trust and norms of reciprocity.

Additionally, our work has developed insights into online communities of practice for humanitarian data development. Through an in-depth analysis of the communication message threads of a Skype chat group, we were able to provide empirical evidence of the process of proto-institutionalization, that is the initial stages of formation of institutions, in a multi-organizational collaboration. Heretofore, theories of proto-institutionalization primarily relied upon anecdotes to explain how members come together to form successful collaborations across organizational boundaries. Our work provides crucial data on this process, while at the same time integrating concepts from Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW) theories. In this way, we build an intellectual bridge between institutional and CSCW theories, enhancing the robustnesses of institutional theory as applied to the online realm. 

These findings will inform managers in the humanitarian and data sciences communities in three specific ways. First, the research promotes a more circumspect approach to articulating the benefits of Big Data for pandemic response. Instead, designing and planning of operations may best rely on smaller scale data analyses for day-to-day operations, while higher level or longer term planning be informed by larger scale analyses associated with Big Data. Second, planning should take into account the established network infrastructure, and where it is sparse either develop expectations of data availability accordingly or prioritize deployment of hastily formed networks. Third, humanitarian data managers should identify and train data brokers, prepared to engage in networks of data sharing. Policies and practices of which data are shareable, with whom, need to be established as far in advance of a crisis as is feasible.
